bestBHT.bht: Blessed are those who weep audibly now, for they shall laugh. The word laugh expresses what in Matthew is called being comforted. This term sharpens the contrast between present sufferings and future blessings. It is like spiritual fodder or food, filling us with righteousness and life. These words are terse but profound. Thus, those who mourn are blessed, for they shall be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, comforted by the consolations of the Spirit.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: liveliness of this word, to express what in Matthew is called being
Marvin Vincent: Shall be filled. See on Matthew 5:6.
Weep [κλαιοντες] . Strictly, to weep audibly. See on qountev, mourn, Matthew 5:4.
Archibald T. Robertson: This sharpens the contrast between present sufferings and the future blessings.
It was used for giving fodder (χορτος) to animals, but here it is spiritual fodder or food.
John Gill: Blessed are ye that hunger now...for ye shall be filled: with righteousness and life.
Blessed are ye that weep now...for ye shall laugh; be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure.
Be comforted with the consolations of the Spirit.

bhtAttempts.bht: Blessed are those who weep audibly now, for they shall laugh. How charming is this word, laugh, which expresses being comforted! It sharpens the contrast between present sufferings and the future blessings. It is like giving spiritual fodder or food, filling us with righteousness and life. These words are terse but carry profound meaning. So, blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, and be comforted with the consolations of the Spirit.
